So I'm going to go over a package that I wrote called ShinyFA, which was released earlier this year. So, I had a client, and it took me a very, very long time to onboard to their application. Grateful for their patience and their guidance, but it was a massive, massive Shiny app. Lots of different files, interconnected functions, the structure of it was challenging. Sometimes you get a shot to your confidence when you're kind of fighting file systems and folders and just not where you want to be.

And so I thought, "Hey, I'm writing Shiny, and that's great, but also I can leverage some of my other skills in R. Why don't I apply that to the overall onboarding and getting to understand what I'm looking at?" And so that worked into a quick little script, a collection of functions where the output on the right-hand side is the file name, and the type, and the name. And having just this level of information in this format was a game changer. It really helped to connect up what I was doing, what changes I was making, how I needed to understand different parts of the code.

And so then that led to the thought process: if it's helping me now, could it help somebody else? And so I turned it into a package which is published on CRAN, and I really hope all y'all can test drive it and let me know if it also helps improve your development when it comes to navigating large Shiny applications.

And so, yes, before AI, it's a nice "someday" project, but with AI, I built this and released it in weeks.
:::

::: {.notes}
A client example that I really love: they needed to scale a data orchestration system for 50+ client dashboards. After understanding their requirements and technical capabilities, GitHub Actions made a lot of sense. I worked with Claude to build this systemâ€”APIs, webhooks, Railway for the VMâ€”really learning as I went.

The architecture: loading data into Supabase with row-level security rules for client isolationâ€”I had a real hand on the wheel there for the data security and governance aspect. Then all those client dashboards written in Quarto, each pulling only their data.

The client needed a repeatable ETL process, secure data layers for persistence, and a shared component template system where they could feature toggle different dashboard aspects on and off. So each client gets their own dashboard, but they all originate from the same template with shared components that can be updated centrally.

I developed this system primarily with Claude Codeâ€”lots of back and forth, lots of learning on my part about writing better GitHub Actions and how to have Actions create PRs in other repositories. This is right-sized enterprise-grade infrastructure built in just a few weeks with Claude's help. This would not have been possible before.
:::

## Client Project Workflow {.smaller}

::: {.incremental}
1. **Understand Requirements** (Human) â†’ Define the problem and technical approach
2. **Generate Implementation** (Claude Code) â†’ Write the initial code
3. **Review & Course-Correct** (Human) â†’ Read every line, check for issues
4. **Iterate Based on Feedback** (Claude Code) â†’ Fix problems, refine solution
5. **Final QA & Delivery** (Human) â†’ Test thoroughly and ship to client
:::

::: {.fragment}
Human decisions at the start, middle and end. AI execution sprinkled in the middle.
:::

::: {.notes}
So my usual client project workflow is:

1. **Understanding the requirements** - defining the problem, the technical approach
2. **Generating some of the implementation** - Claude writes the initial code
3. **Review and course correcting** - reviewing every line, checking for issues
4. **Iterating based on that feedback** - fixing problems, refining the solution
5. **Final QA** - testing thoroughly and then shipping to the client

It's human decisions at the start, the middle, and end, and AI execution sprinkled in the middle.

## Mistake #1: Package Confusion {.smaller}

**Claude doesn't read the docsâ€”just like you when you're rushing**

::: {.incremental}
- **What happened:** Asked Claude about `{shinyfa}` â†’ it hallucinated "Font Awesome icons"
- **The real error:** Like installing a package and guessing without reading vignettes/examples
- **It's not just new packages:** Even with {ggplot2}, Claude confuses function arguments
- **Why this happens:** You're experienced, busy, assume things should come easy, so you circumvent
- **The lesson:** This forces you to **actually read documentation** and verify behavior
- **Fix strategy:** Feed Claude the documentation URL, then it self-corrects
:::

::: {.fragment}
**This mistake makes you better at evaluating package quality and knowing where good docs live.**
:::

::: {.notes}
I'm going to share some mistakes that happened even building this talk with Claude Code.

Claude doesn't always read the docsâ€”just like humans rushing through things. When I had Claude structure the initial slides, it completely hallucinated what the shinyfa package does. It assumed "FA" meant Font Awesome icons. It didn't even install the packageâ€”just guessed about vignettes and examples.

This happens even with established packages like ggplot2. Experience breeds assumptions, and you skip verification.

The lesson: feed Claude documentation URLs so it can self-correct. This actually makes you better at evaluating where good docs live.
:::

---

## Mistake #2: Data Structure Assumptions {.smaller}

**Claude assumes instead of checkingâ€”sound familiar?**

::: {.incremental}
- **What Claude does:** Assumes column names, data types, relationships
- **Example:** Used `avilist_global` (doesn't exist) instead of `avilist_2025`
- **Example:** Assumed lowercase `order_name` when actual column is `Order`
- **Example:** Infers connections between columns instead of asking for lookup tables
- **Why this happens:** Experience breeds assumptions; you skip verification when busy
- **The lesson:** Use **mcptools** to give Claude actual R session context
- **Fix strategy:** `names(data)`, `str(data)`, or let mcptools read your environment
:::

::: {.fragment}
**This mistake teaches you proper data inspection habitsâ€”skills you use constantly.**
:::

::: {.notes}
Claude loves to infer from column names and data types. But sometimes it's just wrong.

Building the AviListR slide, Claude called the dataset `avilist_global`â€”which doesn't exist. It's `avilist_2025`. It also assumed snake_case column names when they actually match the original Excel file's title case.

Experience breeds assumptions. You skip verification. "Well, snake_case is commonplace, right?"

The lesson: leverage MCP tools to give Claude actual access to your R session. If packages are loaded, if objects exist, let MCP integrate and read your environment.

This mistake teaches proper data inspection habitsâ€”skills we should all be using constantly as data practitioners.
:::

---

## Mistake #3: Over-Abstraction {.smaller}

**Why is Claude (or you) always doing it the hard way?**

::: {.incremental}
- **Claude's tendency:** Always reaches for complex solutions first
- **Example:** Tried 3 different Sankey packages with hallucinated functions
- **Example:** Creates nested functions when a simple dplyr chain works
- **Why this happens:** You want to show expertise, build "proper" systems, over-engineer
- **The lesson:** Simple is better. Ask "Why are you doing it the hard way?"
- **Fix strategy:** Ask for multiple options, choose the simplest that works
:::

::: {.fragment}
**This mistake teaches you that simplicity is a skillâ€”recognizing unnecessary complexity.**
:::

::: {.notes}
This is my biggest gripe with Claude. It always reaches for the complex solution first. Always trying to be overly clever.

Building this slide deck, Claude tried creating an intricate Sankey diagram and just started making up functions. Nested functions everywhere when a simple dplyr chain would work.

I think it's pulling from examples where people are showing expertise, building proper systemsâ€”which sometimes leads to over-engineering. Missing the focus: simple is often better.

So I ask Claude a very direct question: "Why are you doing it this way?" Often, because I've spent so much time without AI, I do know the solution. I know the exact packages I want to use.

I ask why, feed it different options, and select the simplest wayâ€”the way I would actually do it. Recognizing unnecessary complexity has been key to guiding this partnership.
:::

## Building Better Prompts from Mistakes {.smaller}

**Each mistake pattern teaches you how to redirect Claude (and yourself)**

::: {.incremental}
- **Package confusion** â†’ Feed documentation links upfront
- **Data assumptions** â†’ Use mcptools, provide `str(data)` output, give lookup tables
- **Over-abstraction** â†’ Ask for multiple approaches, request "simplest solution"
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Learning at Scale:** You encounter these patterns 10x/day instead of 1x/week. Each failure refines your prompting skills AND your R intuition.
:::

::: {.fragment}
**You're not becoming dependentâ€”you're becoming a better technical leader who knows how to redirect when things go wrong.**
:::

::: {.notes}
Here's some tips for building better prompts from these mistakes:

- **Package confusion** â†’ Feed documentation links upfront
- **Data assumptions** â†’ Use MCP tools, give them lookup tables if columns are coded in other ways
- **Over-abstraction** â†’ Ask for multiple approaches, request sometimes the simplest solution to start

Learning at scale: you're going to encounter these patterns so much more than traditional learning. And each failure, I think, helps refine your prompting skills and your R intuition so that you don't make those mistakes and so you can help Claude make those mistakes less.

And I think you become a better technical leader, and you know how to redirect when things go wrong and leverage what you're learning from Claude to bring to the real world as you're interacting with folks to create better software.
:::
